newsitem.title: USA: FUND VIEW - Bramwell hopeful on mid-caps.
newsitem.headline: FUND VIEW - Bramwell hopeful on mid-caps.

text.p: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov 7, Reuter - Mid-cap stocks should ride the coattails of the S&P 500 in terms of growth, and emerge as a good growth sector, according to Elizabeth Brawmell, portfolio manager of the Bramwell Growth Fund.
The former long-time Gabelli fund executive said she expected earnings in the S&P universe to grow about 10 percent in 1997, with the average dividend yield at about two percent.

Unlike some Wall Street strategists who have lamented the low S&P yield, Bramwell is not turned off by the number. "I'd exchange dividend yield for growth any day," said Bramwell, who attended the Charles Schwab annual Institutional conference here.
Bramwell is focusing the bulk of the fund on the mid-cap region, with capitalization from $1 billion to $5 billion.

Bramwell has more than 20 percent of the $135 million fund in the retailing sector, with her biggest holding in Eckerd Corp, at nearly five percent. The bet has paid off as J.C. Penney intends to purchase the drugstore chain.

Bramwell said she has recently increased the fund's exposure in technology shares, including Intel Corp, and Computer Associates. She was also a buyer of Ingram Micro Inc as an initial public offering.
The fund looks for companies that will record long-term unit and earnings growth.

Bramwell said she also considers macroeconomic and political factors. The recent U.S. elections cheered her, especially the Republicans keeping control of the Congress. The GOP is expected to continue to push a pro-business platform.
Other top holdings include Computer Sciences Corp, Robert Half International Inc in the temporary help business, drugstore retailer Walgreen Co, and Northern Trust Co.
The fund has returned about 11.9 percent year to date, while the S&P 500 has rose about 17.6 percent.
